Once again, this explanation, like so many others, gives the impression that "relative" velocity is a "real" velocity. And this is where these explanations always go wrong. Firstly, to get a more logical understanding of the subject, start by replacing the word “relative” with the word "perceived". From the beginning, the narrator is already talking about the velocity “perceived” by an external observer as if it is the “real” velocity. But don’t forget, the “real” velocity of the person firing the pellet is still 0.6c, the “real” velocity of the pellet is still 0.6c. That didn’t miraculously change. It is just the “perceived” velocity that “appears” different to the external observer. Secondly, ask yourself why the Lorentz Transformation incorporates the speed of light? Because the equation is meant to be used by an external observer to measure or predict the “real” state of an object in a moving frame of reference and light is what that observer uses to “perceive” the object from their own frame of reference. It should not be used to conclude that the “real” velocity of an object can never exceed the speed of light, as the video seems to purport. On the contrary, the correct conclusion should be that the Lorentz Transformation can only be used for measuring objects with a “real” combined velocity less than the speed of light, because the observer is limited by the light needed to perceive them. Other equations, perhaps using red and blue shifts, may permit to extend that limit. But always remember, “Relativity" does NOT equal "Reality".

I’m a little disappointed that you didn’t take this opportunity to introduce the concept of rapidity. You regularly refer to speeds of 0.6c which on the surface might seem like an arbitrary value, but is itself rooted in being the speed for which you stretch one diagonal by a factor of 2, and squeeze the other diagonal to 1/2. If you apply consecutive identical shifts to your spacetime globe, these factors of 2 combine multiplicatively. Equivalently, the logarithms of these scaling factors combine additively.

This logarithm is the rapidity, and relativistic rapidities combine exactly the way you expect classical velocities to combine - simply by addition. Where you say that combining the speed of light with something slower is like adding to infinity, that’s exactly what’s going on, just that it happens with rapidity rather than velocity. The rapidity of light is infinite, which you never get to combining finite rapidities.

It’s easy to show that the velocity of an object is the hyperbolic tangent of the rapidity - just walk through getting from the scaling factor of 2 to your velocity of 0.6c (specifically, its (2-1/2)/(2+1/2) c) and putting an exponent in place of the 2.

Then to get the equation for adding velocities, you can convert from velocities to rapidities (by taking hyperbolic arctangents), adding them, then taking the hyperbolic tangent to get back to a velocity. Or better yet, just point out that the rapidity is the more fundamental concept in relativity, and the velocities we’re used to thinking of are an abstraction of them.
